Detected species Conversion or selectivity [%] catalyst 720 Conversion or selectivity [%] catalyst 640 Conversion 64.5 69.6 1,3-Butadiene 50.7 45.4 CO2 28.6 32.8 CO 11.8 10.8 1-Butene 2 2.6 Cis-2-butene 1.3 1.4 Trans-2-butene 1.1 1.1 Ethylene 3.6 3.7 Methane 0.4 0.6 Propylene 0.7 0.6 Oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene with Mo-V-MgO catalysts in a two-zone fluidized bed reactor Julius Rischard a Claudia Antinori b Lubow Maier b Olaf Deutschmann a b ⁎ a Institute for Chemical Technology and Polymer Chemistry, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), 76128 Karlsruhe, Germany Institute for Chemical Technology and Polymer Chemistry Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) Karlsruhe 76128 Germany b Institute of Catalysis Research and Technology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), 76128 Karlsruhe, Germany Institute of Catalysis Research and Technology Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) Karlsruhe 76128 Germany ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute for Chemical Technology and Polymer Chemistry, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), 76128 Karlsruhe, Germany. Fax: +49 721 608 44805. Graphical abstract The oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane has been studied in a two-zone fluidized bed reactor using two Mo-V-MgO catalysts. Both catalysts have been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation and were calcinated at different temperatures. The operating conditions temperature, flow velocity, n-butane inlet height and oxygen/n-butane molar ratio were varied to maximize 1,3-butadiene yield. At suitable conditions, the two-zone fluidized bed reactor can be operated at steady state performing chemical conversion and catalyst regeneration in a single vessel. The regeneration zone at the bottom of the fluidized bed was used to burn coke depositions as well as to fill up lattice oxygen of the catalyst. After regeneration the catalyst particles can reach the reaction zone due to particle mingling inside the fluidized bed. Different behaviors for both catalysts, despite equal metal content, were observed. The catalyst calcinated at lower temperature tends more to coke formation. Raman spectroscopy, XRD, and BET were used to identify the reason for this. With Raman spectroscopy, small graphite particles were identified on the low temperature calcined catalyst surface. These graphite particles seem to be precursors for coke deposition. The Mo-V-MgO catalyst calcinated at 720°C leads to an improved selectivity to 1,3-butadiene being 51% and a 1,3-butadiene yield of 32.7% at steady state. Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation 1,3-Butadiene Two-zone fluidized bed reactor n-Butane 1 Introduction Butenes and 1,3-butadiene are important building-block chemicals. For example 1,3-butadiene is a necessary monomer for the synthetic rubber production. Rising demand of 1,3-butadiene, its decreasing production in conventional crackers, and a low natural gas price increase the interest in the direct production of 1,3-butadiene out of n-butane. There is no commercial plant for the direct 1,3-butadiene production out of n-butane up to now. At the moment, steam crackers are the main production facilities for 1,3-butadiene. Naphtha needs to be used as feedstock to produce sufficient amounts of 1,3-butadiene. Due to the high supply of natural gas, especially in the United States, many steam crackers were reconstructed in order to use light olefins as feedstock. On the one hand ethylene production increases but on the other hand 1,3-butadiene production decreases significantly. However, the global consumption of 1,3-butadiene is predicted to increase over the next years. A combination of all these factors may lead both to higher 1,3-butadiene prices and to 1,3-butadiene shortages. Thus, alternative capabilities to produce 1,3-butadiene become more and more attractive. There are two different paths from n-butane towards 1,3-butadiene. The first one is the dehydrogenation (DH) and the second one is the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) [1]. C 4 H 10 → Pt or Cr C 4 H 6 + 2 H 2 C 4 H 10 + O 2 → Mo or V C 4 H 6 + 2 H 2 O Presently, Pt or Cr based catalysts are the mainly used catalysts for the dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons [1]. However, these catalysts tend to quick deactivation due to coke depositions. Therefore, complex reactor setups are needed for catalyst regeneration. Furthermore, the main products of the dehydrogenation are butenes. Thus, a second dehydrogenation or oxidative dehydrogenation step is necessary to produce 1,3-butadiene in large amounts. In case of the ODH, 1,3-butadiene can be produced in one step with much higher selectivity compared to the DH. Especially Mo and V based catalysts [2–4] in combination with MgO as support are suitable for the ODH of n-butane. Recently, catalysts based on other supports and metals were investigated [5–10]. Due to the exothermic character of the ODH, higher yields at lower temperatures are achievable. All in all the ODH seems to be a very attractive route for a one step reaction from n-butane to 1,3-butadiene. The two-zone fluidized bed reactor (TZFBR) is a promising setup for the DH as well as for the ODH to increase the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene at steady state with high conversion of n-butane [11–14]. Using a counter-flow configuration, the TZFBR facilitates the production of 1,3-butadiene and the regeneration of the catalyst in a single vessel. The dehydrogenation of n-butane [12] and propane [11] were investigated in a TZFBR over Pt-Sn based catalysts, leading to high steady-state yields of butenes, compared to fixed bed and normal fluidized bed reactors. 20wt%V as V2O5 on MgO [14] and 17.8wt% Mo as MoO3 on MgO [13] were used as catalyst for the ODH of n-butane. For both catalysts the TZFBR showed high conversion of n-butane and high selectivity to 1,3-butadiene. Vanadium oxides as well as molybdenum oxides are reported to use lattice oxygen for the oxidative dehydrogenation. Further studies investigate the effects of reactor size, reactor shape and bubble formation [15–20]. Fig. 1 shows a scheme of the TZFBR used in this study. The hydrocarbon inlet is in the upper region of the fluidized bed, the oxygen flows upwards from the bottom. The measurement of concentration profiles of n-butane and oxygen as function of the height above the frit, indicates the development of the two zones inside the fluidized bed [11–14]. In case of the ODH, the lattice oxygen from the catalyst is used in the reaction zone for the selective oxidation of n-butane towards 1,3-butadiene and butenes. The reduced catalyst can reach the regeneration zone due to particle mingling. Here the catalyst is reoxidized by oxygen entering the reactor from below. The regenerated catalyst can return to the reaction zone to be used again. Similar processes may occur in dehydrogenation reactions in a TZFBR with the only difference that here deposited coke is burned off in the regeneration zone. In this study, we investigated the ODH of n-butane in a TZFBR using two Mo-V-MgO catalysts, which are calcinated at different temperatures. The impact of oxygen/n-butane molar ratio, flow velocity, n-butane inlet height, and temperature on the product distribution were investigated. The main focus consisted in the optimization of 1,3-butadiene selectivity and yield. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst MgO (Sigma–Aldrich) was pressed with 5wt% graphite into pellets and these were crushed to a particle size between 160 and 250μm. Afterwards, the particles were impregnated with Mo and V in one step by incipient wetness impregnation. For the impregnation, 6.53g ammonium heptamolybdate tetra aqua (VWR Chemicals) and 1.99g ammonium methavanadate hexa aqua (Merck) were added to 31ml distilled water for 50g catalyst. The suspension was heated to 80°C. While stirring the mixture oxalic acid was added until the solution was colored deep blue. Then the MgO was carefully impregnated with the deep blue solution. The impregnated catalyst was dried for 24h at 120°C. One catalyst was calcinated at 640°C for 8h and the second one at 720°C for 8h in air. In the last step, the catalysts were crushed and sieved to obtain a particle size between 160 and 250μm. The catalyst calcinated at 640°C was gray and the one calcinated at 720°C was yellow. Both catalysts were characterized before and after being on stream for 95h. A Rubotherm Belsorp-mini II was used to measure the BET surface area by N2-physisorption at 77K. As a pretreatment, all samples were degassed at 350°C for 2h under vacuum. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a PANalytical X’Pert Pro powder diffractometer between 20° and 80° (2θ) and an angular step interval of 0.017° using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54Å). Surface Raman spectroscopy was carried out with a Renishaw inVia reflex spectrometer system using a Nd:YAG laser with 100mW at 532nm. To obtain pictures of the studied particles a Research Grade Leica DM2500 microscope was used. The metal loadings of the catalysts were 7wt% Mo and 1.7wt%V. Catalyst 640 is the abbreviation for the catalyst calcinated at 640°C and catalyst 720 for the one calcinated at 720°C. 2.2 Reactor system Fig. 1 shows a sketch of the two-zone fluidized bed reactor used in this study. The reactor consists of a 40cm long quartz tube with inner diameter of 28mm. At the bottom of the reactor a frit (pore size 160–250μm) holds the particles and homogenizes the incoming gas flow. Inside the reactor, a quartz tube (0.2mm inner diameter) serves as n-butane inlet, which can be moved in vertical direction. Furthermore, a movable thermocouple (typeK, Inconel 600) is installed. The product stream leaves the reactor at a side outlet. Downstream of the outlet, the product stream was cooled in a condenser to remove the water. In order to prevent small particles from leaving the fluidized bed, a filter (pore size 15μm) is installed downstream the condenser. Further downstream, the product stream was split by a valve. Approximately 5vol% of the product stream is fed to an online GC (Thermo Fischer Trace 1310), while the remaining gas is burned. A mole sieve column was installed to separate CO, CO2, H2, and O2. After the separation, these gases are quantified with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the hydrocarbon separation and detection, an alumina column and a flame ionization detector (FID) are installed. An electric furnace (HTM Reetz GmbH) is used for heating the reactor. The thermocouple inside the reactor is connected to a controller (Omron, E5CN-H), which automatically adjusts the necessary heating rate for the required temperature inside the reactor. The temperature inside the entire fluidized bed fluctuates by ±5K. All gases were fed with online mass flow controllers (FA Bronkhorst). The catalyst particle size used in this study was in a range of 160–250μm. At room temperature, the minimal fluidization velocity with Ar was 1.64cm/s (610ml(STP)/min). The minimal fluidization velocity at 570°C was distinctly lower 1.22cm/s (140ml(STP)/min), mainly due to the lower water content of the catalyst at this temperature. The flow velocity (μ) was divided by the minimum fluidization velocity (μ min) to obtain the relative velocity μ r. For each study, the reactor was loaded with 30g of one set of the differently calcinated catalysts, leading to a fluidized bed height of approximately 9cm. 2.3 Measuring procedure For all measurements, the amount of n-butane fed was 6.5vol% of the total incoming gas. O2 and the diluent Ar were fed from the bottom of the reactor, in total 93.5%. During all measurements, the thermocouple was placed 4.5cm over the frit and the reactor worked nearly under isothermal conditions. The online GC needs 17min for a complete measurement, leading to an analysis of the product every 17min. The parameters investigated in this study were the oxygen/n-butane molar ratio, the temperature, the n-butane inlet height and the flow velocity (Table 1 ). 2.3.1 Oxygen/n-butane molar ratio Oxygen fluxes were varied between 6.5 and 17vol% of the total inlet flow at 570°C. Molar ratios of oxygen to n-butane are realized in range of 1–2.6 for the given fixed n-butane feed of 6.5vol%. Steady state could not be reached for all oxygen/n-butane ratios due to catalyst deactivation. In those cases, the product composition was taken after 110min time on stream, if the carbon balance closes within ±5%. After each run, the catalyst was regenerated for one hour at 570°C by feeding an oxygen/argon mixture of 1:4 at a flow rate of 0.3slpm from the bottom of the reactor. The same flow rate was used during the measurements. If no catalyst deactivation occurred, defined by steady state after maximum 30min at time on stream, the oxygen feed variation was studied without catalyst regeneration. During all measurements with varying O2 concentration the n-butane inlet height was fixed at 5.25cm above the frit. 2.3.2 n-Butane inlet height (h inlet) The influence of n-butane inlet height on the product composition was studied for heights above the frit from h inlet =0 (n-butane inlet is at the same height as the frit) to 7cm. The oxygen/n-butane molar ratio was fixed at 2.14 for catalyst 640 and 1.9 for catalyst 720, which are the ratios with the highest 1,3-butadiene yields. In case the catalyst was deactivated during operation, defined by a carbon balance lower than 95% after 60min time on stream, the catalyst regeneration was carried out as described above. The flow rate was 0.3 slpm and the reaction temperature was 570°C. Starting at h inlet =0cm, the inlet height was increased by 1cm steps and in smaller steps of 0.5cm between h inlet =4–6cm. 2.3.3 Temperature The temperature was varied in a range from 500 to 620°C by steps of 10°C in the range of 550–590°C and by 30°C outside this range. During the temperature variation, a constant flow rate of 0.3slpm, an oxygen/n-butane molar ratio of 2.14, and a fixed n-butane inlet height of 5.25cm were used. 2.3.4 Flow velocity The flow velocity is divided by the minimal fluidization velocity (0.14slpm) to gain the relative flow velocity μ r. μ r was varied in the range of 1.1–2.5 (0.15slpm up to 0.35slpm) by 0.35 steps at fixed temperature of 580°C, an oxygen/n-butane molar ratio of 1.9 and n-butane inlet height of 5cm. 3 Results and discussion The product composition and aging behavior of both the Mo-V catalysts, one calcined at 640°C the other at 720°C, are compared and discussed. The major focus of this study was the optimization of 1,3-butadiene selectivity and yield. 3.1 Oxygen/n-butane molar ratio The product distributions of both the catalysts are given as function of the oxygen/n-butane ratio in Fig. 2 . In case of catalyst 640, the highest selectivity to 1,3-butadiene was achieved at a molar ratio of 2.15. At molar ratios below 2.15 no steady state was achievable due to catalyst deactivation. To illustrate this behavior, the time depending measurement of catalyst 640 for an oxygen/n-butane ratio of 2.00 is given in Fig. 3 . The 1,3-butadiene selectivity slightly decreases while the selectivity to carbon oxides increases, which can be explained by increasing coke deposition on the catalyst with time on stream. The detection of carbon oxides during the catalyst regeneration after the measurements evidences coke depositions on the catalyst. With decreasing O2 feed, more O2 is used to burn the coke in the regeneration zone and is therefore not available for ODH. The decreasing selectivity to carbon oxides above a molar ratio of 2.15 can be explained in the same way. Higher oxygen/n-butane ratios led to slower catalyst deactivation due to coke depositions and less coke depositions on the catalyst led to less oxygen consumption for coke burning inside the regeneration zone. At ratios above 2.15, the region of balanced deactivation and regeneration was left. Oxygen now participated in oxidation of n-butane and the intermediates, increasing the selectivity to carbon oxides while decreasing the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene. Due to the high coke deposition rate at ratios below 1.5, the reactor could not reach a steady state. Even after 110min on stream, the carbon balance was lower than 90%. The amount of butenes (trans-, 1-, cis-, iso-buten) decreases slowly with increasing oxygen/n-butane molar ratio (Fig. 2). In case of catalyst 720 an oxygen/n-butane molar ratio of 1.9 led to the highest selectivity towards 1,3-butadiene (Fig. 2 right) being 48%. Catalyst 640 showed the highest selectivity to 1,3-butadiene at an oxygen/n-butane molar ratio of 2.15 being 44%. The selectivity towards carbon oxides for catalyst 720 is much lower at ratios below 1.9 than for catalyst 640, which indicates lower coke depositions on catalyst 720 at similar operating conditions. V or Mo based catalysts are known to show the highest yields of 1,3-butadiene at molar ratios between 1.5 and 2.0 [2,13,14]. Using catalyst 640, more oxygen was necessary compared to catalyst 720. Thus, the oxygen was not only used for reoxidation of the catalyst, it was also used to burn the massive coke depositions formed during operation. Investigations of both catalysts with Raman spectroscopy exhibit graphite particles on the surface of catalyst 640 (Fig. 4 ) [21]. The graphite, used for pressing the MgO into pellets, was not burned completely in case of catalyst 640, due to the low calcination temperature of 640°C. No graphite particles were observed on the surface of catalyst 720. The graphite might be a precursor for coke deposition on the surface. The XRD diagrams (Fig. 4) of both catalysts exhibit small amounts of Mg3V2O8 as well as MgMoO4. Compared to catalyst 640, the MgMoO4 content of catalyst 720 seems to be higher and the Mg3V2O8 lower. No different coke deposition rates were observed using Mo-V-MgO catalysts with various V and Mo contents for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane [3]. Graphite could not be detected in the XRD spectrum of catalyst 640, likely due to single graphite particles distributed on the surface of catalyst 640 (Fig. 5 left). Concerning the specific surface areas (Table 2 ) no significant differences could be observed after 95h on stream. 3.2 n-Butane inlet height The height of the n-butane inlet is an important parameter in a TZFBR. The selectivities to COx, 1,3-butadiene and the conversion of n-butane are a function of the n-butane inlet height (Fig. 6 ). In case of catalyst 640, significant variations in conversion and even more in selectivity were observed between h inlet =4.5–5.5cm above the frit. Increasing the n-butane inlet height from h inlet =4.5cm up to h inlet =5 cm, the 1,3-butediene selectivity increased from 38% up to 47%. At a position of h inlet =5cm, 1,3-butadiene was the most favored product. For an increase of the n-butane inlet height to h inlet =5.5cm significantly lower selectivity towards 1,3-butadiene of 41,5% and much higher selectivity to carbon oxides of 54% compared to h inlet =5 were observed. However, the decrease of the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene were not as large as for the step from h inlet =4.5 cm to h inlet =5 cm. All measuring points in Fig. 6 were taken after 110min on stream. In order to explain the strong impact of the n-butane inlet height for the ODH on catalyst 640, n-butane conversion and selectivity to 1,3-buatdiene, COx and butenes are shown as function of the time on stream for h inlet =4.5cm and 5.5cm in Fig. 7 . In both cases, the selectivity towards 1,3-butadiene was lower compared to its selectivity at h inlet =5cm after 110min on stream. In contrast, the selectivity to carbon oxides increased. The data indicate that different reasons are responsible for deactivation in the cases of h inlet =4.5cm and h inlet =5.5cm. At h inlet =4.5cm both the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene and conversion of n-butane slowly decrease from 42.5% to 38% and 74 to 66%, respectively, during 110min time on stream while the selectivity to carbon oxides increase from 48% to 54%. As already discussed concerning the variation of oxygen/n-butane molar ratio, the catalyst mainly deactivates due to coke deposition. At h inlet <4.5cm, a faster decrease compared to h inlet =4.5 in selectivity of 1,3-butadien and n-butane conversion was observed. There are two possible explantations for the catalyst deactivation at these lower n-butane inlet positions. First, the longer contact time, due to the larger reaction zone at lower h inlet positions, supports coke formation. Second, the contact time in the regeneration zone is too small to regenerate the catalyst completely with the oxygen coming from the bottom, burning off the coke and reoxidizing the catalyst. Thus, coke deposits increasingly deactivate catalyst 640 and the oxygen is increasingly used for total and partial oxidation of n-butane. The same effect was observed for catalyst 640 at low oxygen/n-butane ratios. At the relative flow velocity μ r =2.14, the allover contact time of the gases fed at the bottom in the catalyst bed was approximately 11.6s. This time varies by approximately 0.5s, due to the changing height of the fluidized bed caused by bubble formation. Thus, the approximated contact times are 5.5s inside the regeneration zone and 6.1s inside the reaction zone for h inlet =4.5cm. For h inlet =5.5cm (Fig. 7), the reactor reached a steady-state behavior after approx. 50min. This is probably caused by the lower contact time of the n-butane in the catalytic bed. The lower contact time inside the reaction zone for h inlet =5.5cm led to less coke formation on the catalyst and to a lower amount of reduced catalyst due to lower 1,3-butadiene formation. Therefore less oxygen is consumed inside the regeneration zone and this leftover oxygen reaches the reaction zone. Thus, a direct reaction between n-butane and oxygen is possible, leading to an increase of total and partial oxidation products. Further increase of the n-butane inlet height led to lower 1,3-butadiene selectivity and lower n-butane conversion. A balance between the optimal contact times, necessary for reaction (5.5s) and catalyst regeneration (6.1s), were found for h inlet =5cm. In case of catalyst 720, the same optimal inlet height of h inlet =5cm is observed (Fig. 6). However, the variations in selectivity to 1,3-butadiene due to small changes of the inlet height were significantly lower for catalyst 720 than for catalyst 640. For example, the 1,3-butadiene selectivity decreased by 3% only, when the n-butane inlet height was changed from h inlet =5cm to h inlet =4cm as well as to h inlet =6cm. 3.3 Temperature Both catalysts showed the best performance at temperatures between 570 and 580°C (Fig. 8 , shown for catalyst 720). The selectivity to 1,3-butadiene remains the same in this temperature range. However, due to higher conversion, 1,3-butadiene yield increases by 2% from 570°C to 580°C. At temperatures below 570°C, total- and partial oxidation were more pronounced reactions. The amount of crack products increased with higher temperatures, simultaneously decreasing the selectivity to 1,3-butadiene. 3.4 Flow rate Flow velocities between μ r =1 and μ r =1.5 exhibited a lower selectivity to 1,3-butadiene and a higher one to COx and crack products (Fig. 9 ). Insufficient particle exchange between the two zones, due to the low flow velocity explains this behavior. Thus, the two zones did not develop in the reactor. At flow velocities μ r above 2.1, good particle exchange between both zones existed. However, a lower selectivity to 1,3-butadiene was observed. Bubble formation and lower contact time in both zones probably caused these observations. The best results were obtained with a flow velocity of μ r =1.8, which probably is due to the achievement of the right contact times in both zones as well as sufficient particle exchange. For the catalyst 640, flow velocities below μ r =1.5 resulted in too small particle exchange between the reaction and the regeneration zone to reactivate the catalyst by burning the coke depositions. At higher flow velocities, we observed a similar behavior as for catalyst 720. 3.5 Optimized conditions Fig. 10 shows the n-butane conversion, selectivity and yield to 1,3-butadiene as well as the selectivity to carbon oxides for both catalysts as function of time on stream under optimized reaction conditions based on the results discussed above. The TZFBR reaches a steady state with catalyst 640 after approx. 80min. At steady state, the n-butane conversion for catalyst 640 was 69.0% with a selectivity of 45.5% to 1,3-butadiene. The selectivity to all dehydrogenated C4 products was above 50%. Even after 95h usage, no catalyst deactivation was observed. With catalyst 720, the TZFBR reached quickly a steady state after approx. 5min on stream. Compared to catalyst 640, the 1,3-butadiene selectivity for catalyst 720 is 5.2% higher. The 1,3-butadiene yield for catalyst 640 was 31.5% and for catalyst 720 32,7%. Table 3 shows the selectivity to all detected species at the optimized conditions for catalyst 720 and catalyst 640 at steady state. During long term measurements, a yellow solid was deposited in the refrigeration unit with both catalysts. The yield of the condensate was too low to consider it as product. NMR study of the condensate suggested a polyaromatic structure. We assume that these condensates are polymerization products of 1,3-butadiene or butenes. Santamaria et al. showed that the TZFBR provides high selectivity to 1,3-butadiene with V or Mo catalysts [13,14]. The Mo-V based catalysts used in our study exhibit even higher yields and higher selectivity to 1,3-butadiene than previously described in a TZFBR or fixed bed reactor. Compared to Mo doped V-MgO catalysts, tested in a fixed bed reactor, the 1,3-butadiene selectivity is higher by 12.5% [3] and compared to those used in a TZFBR by 7%. On top of that, the used metal content of the catalyst was lower. The values of the optimized operating conditions are comparable to other studies [13,14]. As seen in the results, the optimal inlet height is an important reaction parameter. Even small differences can lead to high variations in product composition, as shown for catalyst 640 (Fig. 6). The minimum fluidization velocity is lower compared to other catalysts used in a TZFBR [12–14]. Thus, the contact times inside the catalytic bed are higher for the studied range of the flow velocity. Therefore, small variations of the inlet height may have a stronger effect on the product composition due to the higher variations of the contact times inside the regeneration as well as the reaction zone compared to higher flow velocities. Furthermore, MgO seems to be the necessary support for the ODH of n-butane to gain high selectivity to 1,3-butadiene with V, Mo or V-Mo based catalysts [4–10,22]. 4 Conclusion Two Mo-V-MgO based catalysts, one calcinated at 640°C (catalyst 640) and one at 720°C (catalyst 720), were shown to be suitable for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of n-butane using a two-zone fluidized bed reactor (TZFBR), with a regeneration and a reaction zone, efficiently using the oxygen. Thorough variation of the operating conditions led to optimal conditions for maximizing 1,3-butadiene yield and selectivity. In case of both catalysts, 1,3-butadiene was the main product with yields higher than 30%. Catalyst 720 shows distinctly higher selectivity to 1,3-butadiene and additionally higher 1,3-butadiene yields than catalyst 640. Thus, higher calcination temperatures should be preferred in order to avoid strong coke formation caused by residues of catalyst preparation. The TZFB-technology in combination with the highly active catalyst 720 may offer an interesting alternate route for the production of 1,3-butadiene from n-butane. coredata.dc:description: The oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane has been studied in a two-zone fluidized bed reactor using two Mo-V-MgO catalysts. Both catalysts have been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation and were calcinated at different temperatures. The operating conditions temperature, flow velocity, n-butane inlet height and oxygen/n-butane molar ratio were varied to maximize 1,3-butadiene yield. At suitable conditions, the two-zone fluidized bed reactor can be operated at steady state performing chemical conversion and catalyst regeneration in a single vessel. The regeneration zone at the bottom of the fluidized bed was used to burn coke depositions as well as to fill up lattice oxygen of the catalyst. After regeneration the catalyst particles can reach the reaction zone due to particle mingling inside the fluidized bed. Different behaviors for both catalysts, despite equal metal content, were observed. The catalyst calcinated at lower temperature tends more to coke formation. Raman spectroscopy, XRD, and BET were used to identify the reason for this. With Raman spectroscopy, small graphite particles were identified on the low temperature calcined catalyst surface. These graphite particles seem to be precursors for coke deposition. The Mo-V-MgO catalyst calcinated at 720°C leads to an improved selectivity to 1,3-butadiene being 51% and a 1,3-butadiene yield of 32.7% at steady state.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene with Mo-V-MgO catalysts in a two-zone fluidized bed reactor
